question: Unless otherwise specified, a control zone is
options: A. the same as a control area.
B. controlled airspace around an aerodrome that extends vertically from the surface to 3,000 feet AGL.
D. controlled airspace along airways above 2,200 feet ASL.

question: Would the Regulations be violated, if a pilot voluntarily landed an aircraft in bright moonlight at an aerodrome where the length of the landing area was indicated by a single row of white lights?
options: A. There would be no violation, provided the lights were in the centre of the landing area.
B. There would be no violation, provided the aeroplane was equipped with a functioning landing light.
C. Yes, the CAR for aerodrome minimum lighting would have been violated.
D. There would be no violation, provided air to ground communication was available.

question: “Day” in Canada is defined as that period of time between
options: B. one hour before sunrise and one hour after sunset.
C. the end of morning civil twilight and the beginning of evening civil twilight.
D. the beginning of morning civil twilight and the end of evening civil twilight.

question: No person shall walk, drive or park a vehicle on any part of an uncontrolled aerodrome used for the movement of aircraft except in accordance with permission given by
options: A. the operator of the aerodrome.
B. a qualified representative of a commercial air service being operated from the aerodrome.

question: No person shall fly or attempt to act as a flight crew member of an aircraft if that person
options: A. is less than 18 years of age.
B. has consumed alcohol or drugs 48 hours prior to take-off.
C. is suffering or is likely to suffer from fatigue.
D. is over 60 years of age.

question: A person may conduct aerobatic manoeuvres in an aircraft
options: A. only when no passengers are carried.
B. over a built-up area above 2,000 feet AGL.
C. within Class F advisory airspace when visibility is 3 miles or greater.
D. within Class C advisory airspace when the visibility is greater than 1 NM.

question: When two aircraft are converging at approximately the same altitude, the aircraft that has the other on its right shall give way except that
options: A. aeroplanes shall give way to rotary wing aircraft.
B. helicopters shall give way to aeroplanes.
C. gliders shall give way to aeroplanes.
D. power-driven heavier-than-air aircraft shall give way to airships, gliders and balloons.

question: When two aircraft are approaching head-on or approximately so and there is danger of collision, each pilot shall
options: A. alter heading to the right.
B. alter heading to the left.
C. avoid the other by changing altitude.
D. turn on the anti-collision lights.

question: Pilots are responsible for taking action as necessary to avoid a collision
options: A. unless flying in accordance with an ATC clearance.
B. only when flying in VFR conditions.
C. except when within visual range of the control tower.

question: If ice has accumulated on an aerofoil in flight, the stalling speed will
options: B. decrease in all flight conditions.
C. increase in level flight only.
D. increase in all flight conditions.

question: The indicated stalling speed of an aeroplane
options: A. is higher when flying downwind than upwind.
D. does not change with change of altitude.

question: The stalling speed of an aeroplane
options: A. is the same in a co-ordinated turn as in straight and level flight.
B. is less in a co-ordinated turn than in straight and level flight.
C. is greater in a co-ordinated turn than in straight and level flight.
D. increases in climbing turns, decreases in gliding turns.

question: The use of low octane fuel in a high compression engine may result in
options: A. too lean a mixture for best operation.
C. fouling of the spark plugs.

question: If one magneto should fail on an engine equipped with dual ignition
options: A. a slight loss of power would result.
B. there would be no effect on the engine.
D. half of the cylinders would not fire.

question: The use of carburettor heat will
options: A. increase manifold pressure and enrich the mixture.
B. increase manifold pressure and lean out the mixture.
C. decrease manifold pressure and enrich the mixture.
D. decrease manifold pressure and lean out the mixture.

options: A. in clear air with high relative humidity at above freezing temperatures.
B. only when precipitation is present at freezing temperatures.
C. only in cloud with high relative humidity.
D. only when water droplets are in suspension in the air.

question: Prolonged idling of an aircraft engine would most likely cause
options: B. backfiring in the induction system.

question: Ground effect will enable an aeroplane to become airborne below normal flying speed primarily due to
options: B. a decrease in induced drag.
D. an increase in wing tip vortices.

question: Relative humidity is the
options: A. amount of moisture present in the air.
B. weight of water present in the air.
C. amount of moisture present in the air compared to the amount the air could hold at that temperature and pressure.
D. temperature to which the air must be lowered to bring about saturation.

question: The cloud type usually associated with steady rain is
Clouds form when moist warm air overruns cold air because the warm air
options: A. is cooled by the cold air underneath.
B. is cooled by the surrounding cold air aloft.
C. becomes unstable as a result of cooling from below.
D. cools as a result of expansion as it rises.

question: Advection fog forms when
options: A. moist air moves from a warm surface to a colder surface.
B. the cold ground cools the air in contact with it at night.
C. moist air is influenced by orographic effect.
D. moist cool air moves from a cold surface to a warm surface.

question: Radiation fog forms as a result of the
options: A. passage of cold air over a warm surface.
B. air becoming moist as it moves over the sea.
C. clouds becoming cold and heavy at night so that they settle to the ground.
D. ground becoming cold at night and cooling the air in contact with it.

question: In the northern hemisphere, the winds blow
options: A. clockwise around high and low pressure areas.
B. counter-clockwise around high and low pressure areas.
C. clockwise around a high pressure area and counter-clockwise around a low pressure area.
D. counter-clockwise around a high pressure area and clockwise around a low pressure area.

options: A. veer and increase in speed.
B. veer and decrease in speed.

D. back and decrease in speed.

B. temperature rises owing to increased pressure.
